net.varkhan.base.containers
Interface HashingStrategy<Type>

Type Parameters:
Type - the type of object on which the algorithms operate
All Superinterfaces:
java.io.Serializable
All Known Subinterfaces:
DoubleHashingStrategy, FloatHashingStrategy, IntHashingStrategy, LongHashingStrategy
public interface HashingStrategy<Type>
extends java.io.Serializable

A coordinated pair of hash-code and equality computing algorithms.

Implementations of this interface provide a method testing for equality of two objects of a given type, and a method to compute hash-codes for this type of object, that returns a unique value for all objects that test equal.

Field Summary
static HashingStrategy<java.lang.Object> DefaultHashingStrategy
          The default hashing strategy, that use the default #hashCode() and #equals(Object) methods.
static HashingStrategy<java.lang.Object> ReferenceHashingStrategy
          The reference-based hashing strategy, that use the reference frame pointer as hash code, and reference identity to define equality.
 
Method Summary
 boolean equal(Type o1, Type o2)
          Indicates whether two objects are equal to each other.

          Compute the hash code of an object.

Method Detail

hash

long hash(Type o)
Compute the hash code of an object.

Whenever this method is invoked on the same object more than once during an execution of a Java application, it must consistently return the same value, provided no information used in equals comparisons on the object is modified.

If two objects are equal according to the equal(Object, Object) method, then calling this method on each of the two objects must produce the same result.

Parameters:
o - the object
Returns:
the object's hash code

equal

boolean equal(Type o1,
              Type o2)
Indicates whether two objects are equal to each other.

This method implements an equivalence relation on object references, which means it is:

  • reflexive: for any reference value x, equals(x, x) must return true.
  • symmetric: for any reference values x and y, equals(x, y) must return true if and only if equals(y,x) returns true.
  • transitive: for any reference values x, y, and z, if equals(x, y) returns true and equals(y, z) returns true, then equals(x, z) must return true.
  • consistent: for any reference values x and y, multiple invocations of equals(x, y) consistently return true or consistently return false, provided no information in the objects is modified.
equals(null, null) must return true, and for any non-null reference value x, equals(x, null) must return false.

Parameters:
o1 - an object to compare
o2 - an other object to compare
Returns:
true if the objects are equal
